climbs.name: Unforgettable Fire
climbs.fa: Glenn Shuler, Kevin McLaughlin, Wayne Smith, 2001

content.description:
This climb starts by clipping the first 5 bolts of

The Green Mile

. From here, you move to the left along a ramp which is protectable in a crack. I used gear as big as a #1 Camalot on this pitch, although Jason Haas says in his book to rack up to a #0.75 Camalot. I did use the #0.75. There are bolts from which to belay. The second pitch goes up the slab above following a protruding dike. This pitch is protected by 13 bolts with a bolt anchor at the top. The pitch is fun but not too hard for a 5.9. You better like slabs if you do this climb!
content.protection: Five bolts and a rack to about a #1 Camalot on the first pitch and thirteen bolts on the second pitch. There are bolt anchors after both pitches.
content.location:
This route starts with the first 5 bolts of

The Green Mile

but moves left and is the left most route on the rock. You rappel the route to descend which takes two ropes to get down the second pitch. The route starts on

The Green Mile

.

climbs.name: Sour Milk
climbs.fa: Jason Haas, Mike Morin, Joe Sambataro, March 2013

content.description: This route starts up a left-facing flake going to its top and then goes up a black streak. Near the top, you climb left of the black streak to the anchor.  This route feels easier than the other slab routes on the rock and gives you a good break if you save it for last. It is worth doing.
content.protection:
Top rope from anchors at top which can be reached from

Half and Half

.
content.location:
This route is right of

Half and Half

and is the furthest right route on the rock.

content.description: This route starts up a left-facing corner protected by gear in a crack. At the top of the corner, bolts lead up a slab to the anchor. My partner and I both though this felt hard for its 5.8 rating. It did not seem much easier that the 9s to the left. Then again, after so much slab climbing, we may have been jaded. This route is as fun as the others, and you do get to play with some trad gear.
content.protection: 11 bolts and a rack to a #2 Camalot. There is a bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
This route is to the right of

The Green Mile

and is the middle of the 5 routes on the rock.

climbs.name: Half and Half
climbs.fa: Jason Haas, Joe Sambataro, Mike Morin, March 2013

content.description: This is a fun route and seemed to be the hardest of the three 5.9 routes on the rock. The crux is about a third of the way up on thin slab moves.  Most of the holds are small on this rock, but the crux holds almost did not seem to exist.  It seemed like just smooth rock.  A 70m rope just barely gets you down, it seemed like the route was 120' long.
content.location:
This route is to the right of

Phoenix

and is the furthest right bolted route on the rock. There are raspberry bushes at the base. You descend from the anchor at the top.

content.description: This climb goes up for two pitches, and it is the second route, but first line of bolts, on the left side of the rock. The first pitch is 5.8 in difficulty with a crux above the last bolt. The second pitch is 5.9 and is about 125' long. This pitch has a lot of bolts on it. My partner and I both thought it was on the easy side of 5.9. The best holds are small, it is a definite slab climb.
content.protection: Seven bolts to anchors on the first pitch and fifteen bolts to anchors on the second pitch.
content.location: This route is the first bolt line you will see on the left side of the rock.  The first bolt is about 40' up but the initial climbing is easy.  There are raspberry bushes at the bottom.  You do two rappels to descend and the first rap requires two ropes.
